thread.title: MARKET SNAPSHOT: Microsoft, Amazon, Former Google Headline Third-quarter's Earnings Peak Week
thread.title_full: MARKET SNAPSHOT: Microsoft, Amazon, Former Google Headline Third-quarter's Earnings Peak Week

author: morningstar.com
title: MARKET SNAPSHOT: Microsoft, Amazon, Former Google Headline Third-quarter's Earnings Peak Week
text:
By Wallace Witkowski, MarketWatch
More than one-fifth of S&P 500, one-third of Dow report results
Microsoft Corp., Amazon.com Inc., and the results of the company formerly known as Google--now Alphabet Inc.-- will headline what is set to be a flurry of third-quarter earnings.
Given that a large chunk of the Dow's 30 components and the S&P 500 are reporting, those results are crucial to counteracting a big expected drag from energy and materials earnings declines next week.
Telecom makes a big show this week with Verizon Communications Inc.(VZ) and AT&T Inc.(T) earnings, with the sector expected to show the largest earnings growth of the season at 18.1%.
Quarterly results for consumer-discretionary stocks are expected to see the second strongest earnings growth from a year ago with a forecast rise of 9.7%. Big names this week include Amazon.com (AMZN), McDonald's Corp.(MCD), Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc.(CMG), and General Motors Co.(GM)
It will take some of the biggest names in tech like Alphabet (GOOGL) (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT), and International Business Machines Corp.(IBM), however, to pull that heavily-weighted sector out above its expected 0.1% growth from a year ago.
More than 100 S&P 500 companies are scheduled to report this week, with 12 of those Dow components.
Dow 30 components reporting earnings this week
Report date Company/ticker (FactSet EPS / revenue consensus estimate) Mon., Oct. 19 IBM ($3.31 / $19.64 billion) Tues., Oct. 20 United Technologies Corp. US:UTX ($1.56 / $14.82 billion) Verizon ($1.02 / $32.95 billion)Travelers Cos. US:TRV ($2.25 / $6.12 billion) Weds., Oct. 21 Coca-Cola Co. US:KO (50 cents / $11.56 billion)Boeing Co. US:BA ($2.20 / $24.73 billion)American Express Co. US:AXP ($1.31 / $8.31 billion) Thurs., Oct. 22 Microsoft (58 cents / $20.75 billion)3M Co. US:MMM ($2.01 / $7.86 billion)Caterpillar Inc. US:CAT (78 cents / $11.33 billion)McDonald's ($1.27 / $6.42 billion) Fri., Oct. 23 Procter & Gamble Co. US:PG (95 cents / $17.39 billion)
So far, the season is off to a brisk start with actual earnings growth coming in at 7.5% based on the 58 companies that have already reported, with 71% of companies topping consensus earnings estimates, according to Thomson Reuters data.
That is in line with the recent earnings season trend where companies reporting near the beginning of the season beat their earnings estimates more often than later-reporting companies, according to Pierre Lapointe, head of global strategy and markets at Pavilion Global Markets, in a recent note. However, that is less surprising when one takes into account that energy and materials companies tend to report later in the calendar.
Ten out of the 15 companies in the financial sector that have reported have topped earnings estimates. By contrast, only six out of the 11 consumer-discretionary companies that have reported beat estimates, seven out of 10 industrials have, and eight out of nine tech companies have delivered better-than-expected quarterly results, according to Thomson Reuters.
When taking into account a blended-earnings rate--actual earnings combined with estimates for companies that have yet to report--that is improved the anticipated-earnings decline for the S&P 500 to 4.6%, compared with a 5.5% decline a little over a week ago, according to John Butters, senior earnings analyst at FactSet.
The relatively strong start to the season, however, needs to be taken with a grain of salt, as the bulk of energy and materials earnings, the biggest expected drag on S&P 500 earnings growth, won't come out in full force until next week.
